Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Sensing and Smart Systems

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award establishes a new Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site at Florida Atlantic University. Faculty in the Institute for Sensing and Embedded Network Systems Engineering will host cohorts of undergraduate students for summer research in the area of sensing and smart systems. Smart systems represent an emerging class of distributed systems that provide real-time awareness of conditions, trends, and patterns to support improved decision-making and automated control. Smart systems offer a significant application potential that should be appealing to undergraduate researchers. The recruitment and selection procedures will ensure that the program engages a diverse demographic, including a significant number of women and veterans as well as members of underrepresented minorities. Many of the participants will be recruited from institutions where there are limited research opportunities for undergraduates. In addition to conducting research the students will participate in other professional development activities such as industry field trips, professional seminars, speakers, career guidance, and graduate school preparation. An external evaluator will measure the success of the site and the impact on the students. The culminating event of the summer will be a mini-conference where the students present their research results in a professional setting.

The REU site is led by faculty mentors from the Institute for Sensing and Embedded Network Systems Engineering. The faculty of the Institute have significant research expertise and offer state-of-the-art facilities that should provide a compelling research experience to undergraduates. The undergraduates will be woven into existing research groups and projects that are working on current and emerging applications that have real-world connections. The research will focus on three main areas of application expertise including infrastructure systems, marine and environment, and health and behavior. The projects span diverse contexts of exploration and application unified in their focus on sensing and smart systems. The resulting exploration space presents a myriad of challenges at the confluence of computing and data-intensive science and engineering. The site focus and associated research projects present and outstanding opportunity for catalyzing interdisciplinary exploration and discovery that will excite students and demonstrate scientific discovery and exploration at a high level.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Advancements in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) are the leading drivers of economic growth in the United States. Future advancements depend on the availability of a skilled STEM workforce. For the United States to maintain its position as a global economic leader, STEM pipeline programs must be strengthened to ensure a diverse, well-qualified, and globally competitive next-generation workforce. To help meet this need, Florida Atlantic University's Institute for Sensing and Embedded Network Systems Engineering (I-SENSE) hosted an interdisciplinary REU site during the summers of 2017-2019, with a programmatic focus on sensing and smart systems.  

Closely related to the Internet of Things, smart systems provide real-time awareness of conditions, trends, and patterns to support improved decision-making and automated control. These systems find broad application in healthcare, urban planning, civil engineering, oceanography, and numerous other domains. This diversity of application makes them especially appealing as the focus of an REU site, attracting interest across diverse STEM disciplines and fostering an emphasis on interdisciplinary research training.

The REU site engaged a diverse cohort (~30 students) of high-potential undergraduates from across the country. The main purpose was to provide students with the opportunity to participate in meaningful research that would encourage their pursuit of graduate studies in STEM. Specific objectives for the program included: (1) The REU site was designed to cultivate participants' technical, interpersonal, and communication skills through structured training seminars, activities, and workshops. (2) The REU site was designed to positively impact participants' beliefs in their abilities to conduct research, and ultimately, to excel in STEM career pathways. Participants received career mentoring during the REU experience, and some maintain contact with their mentors. (3) The REU site was designed to ignite participants' interest and improve their capacity to engage in interdisciplinary research. The approach relied on immersive, individualized research training in areas that emphasize interdisciplinary problem solving and collaboration. (4) The REU site sought to promote the development of a supportive, cohesive, and engaged community of students through group activities and colocation in a shared laboratory. 

The evaluation results reflect a successful program. Participants and mentors consistently reported finding significant value in the REU site. Participants were able to articulate specific learning outcomes that were achieved due to their participation. Many of these were directly related to the content of their projects (e.g., learning how to code in a new programming language, producing materials or data through novel processes, acquiring new strategies to solve particular problems). Other learning outcomes centered on transferrable skills' valuable in academe or in the workplace (e.g., working as part of a team, time management, self-advocacy). Likewise, faculty mentors felt that their research programs benefitted from REU participation; they saw increases in productivity and enjoyed a sense of community that developed among mentors and mentees. Some mentors expressed that their work with mentees created an opportunity for them to take a step back from their own research activity to reflect on the "how's" and "why's" of their research programs. Most exciting of all, most participants expressed that they understood more about research and the process of exploring and applying to graduate school because of the activities and workshops that were held throughout the program.
